channel.title: New local problems on FixMyStreet
channel.description: The latest local problems reported by users

item.title: Well Place never cleaned., 15th June
item.description:
The parking in Well Placd is for a six hour limit. It’s a favourite ‘wait zone’ for taxis but other parked vehicles also us the street as a public rubbish bin when they park up, eat lunch & then deposit litter & contents of car ashtrays in the gutters. The street is never cleaned. I ‘litter pick’ as required & sweep the pavement.
Nearest road to the pin placed on the map (automatically generated by OpenStreetMap): 5, Well Place, Warden Hill, Cheltenham
Report on FixMyStreet

item.title: Dangerous Junction, 15th June
item.description:
The five way junction of Douro Road, Malvern Place, Well Place & Lansdown Parade has lost most of its markings - it’s a dangerous junction especially for pedestrians & cars emerging from Well Place you…….. traffic does not ‘give way’ when emerging from Lansdown Parade.
Nearest road to the pin placed on the map (automatically generated by OpenStreetMap): Malvern Place, Warden Hill, Cheltenham
Report on FixMyStreet

item.title: The new pavement in West Approach Drive has no kerb and cars are mounting the pavement., 14th June
item.description:
West Approach Drive was given a new pavement along with the Evesham Road cycle lane. This road is the main approach to the Pump Room which is the premier building in Cheltenham. The new pavement is very shoddy. It is only wide enough for one pedestrian and has no kerb. Consequently cars that are doing u turns at the end of West Approach Drive ( a cul de sac) are continually mounting the pavement. This is dangerous for pedestrians and ruins the grass area. See picture. The quality of construction of the pavement is very shabby for such an important road and a kerb need to be constructed.

Nearest road to the pin placed on the map (automatically generated by OpenStreetMap): West Approach Drive, Marle Hill, Cheltenham
Report on FixMyStreet

item.title: The edge of the road surface has collapsed, producing a lengthy depression, several inches deep at worst. Hard to spot and avoid in the dark, and, were heavy rain to flood it, impossible to gauge the ddepth at any time. I'm not sure how long the problem has existed, but several weeks at least, probably longer., 14th June
